awd_titl_txt: Standard Grant: ToxicDocs Research Infrastructure Project
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a research infrastructure project called ToxicDoc. It will enable easy access and use of millions of documents for multi-disciplinary research. Recent class-action tort litigation has unearthed millions of previously secret internal records from private firms responsible for wide-scale introduction of toxic substances, such as asbestos and polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs). These documents include memos between executives, unpublished scientific studies, planning documents for public relations campaigns, letters to policymakers, and trade association meeting minutes. Although technically part of the public record, this material is extremely hard to access, even for scientific researchers. ToxicDocs will provide a critical intellectual resource for scholars in multiple fields examining health, toxics, and corporate action. Expected users include scholars in environmental and health history, critical legal studies, hazards geography, environmental health and environmental justice research.

ToxicDocs will use high performance computing methods that quickly renders millions of documents into a full-text searchable format and thereby enable researchers to shed new light on interactions among manufacturers, regulatory agencies, and the scientific community, and to show how various stakeholders responded to knowledge of potential health risks. It leverages recent innovations in database management and web development to create an efficient and fast user experience. The project includes the development of a host of tools for textual analysis: a ToxicDocs Relationship Miner that enables researchers to extract frequently occurring names, organizations, and places from the database and map their network relations; an automated document classifier that categorizes documents; and a Time-Series Machine that enables users to trace the frequency of phrases across time. Without taking any particular side, ToxicDocs will provide an empirical base for informed policy debates that are grounded in key historical records.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Toxic Docs began as a project with a simple quest: organize millions of once-secret documents on industrial poisons, many of which were in complete disarray. These documents emerged from high-stakes tort litigation when judges ordered the vaults of major and minor firms opened. But opening a vault was one thing; collating its contents was another challenge entirely.

Today, Toxic Docs (www.toxicdocs.org) is the world's largest database of once-secret documents on toxic substances. It contains material on PCBs, polyvinyl chloride, lead, asbestos, dioxin, silica, and PFAS. Its collections expanded from an initial core set of documents, as environmental health organizations and other law firms discovered the site and donated material they had accumulated. Internal corporate records are also no longer the only kinds of documents on the site. It now contains material garnered from federal Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) requests and state-level freedom of information laws. These records are critical, as locating such material through traditional national and federal archives, especially for underfunded government agencies, is often incredibly onermous.

Behind the website is a unique pipeline that ingests documents, from physical form all the way to storage in a database. Toxic Docs makes use of new innovations in cloud compouting and database technology so that the process is extremely fast, with ingesting of thousands of pages taking mere minutes before appearance on the site. Search times are also fast; the average search takes less than 1 second to appear.

Towards the end of the project, a companion website, Toxic Tools, was also created. It contains tools that allow the user to explore the database through means beyond the keyword, full-text search. These include the listing of recurring names, places, and organization; automatic document type detection; and inference of social network relationships. Toxic Tools is an ongoing endeavor that will expand with future iterations of the project. Our goal is the creation of tools that will ultimately be cross-portable: usable on documents beyond just the kind currently in Toxic Docs.

Beyond the database itself, Toxic Docs material was used in dozens of scholarly articles and books, plus major print and televisual media, including two nationally televised documentaries and high-profile series on lead. A less successful endeavor was a social media outreach project. Investigators underestimated the time commitment required, and more important, lacked the generational savvy and felicity with social media platforms. Compounding the problem: the popular platforms constantly changed. Thus a strategy that worked well with Facebook did not with, say, TikTok. An undergraduate research assistant has been hired to help rectify this in future incarnations of the project.

The National Science Foundation's support was absolutely critical to the project's success. Above all, it is now a permanent, undeletable repository of material that allows for sober, non-partisan, non-ideological, objective analysis of how a new world of environmental health risk came to be.
